briefdescription.para: Converts a NumPy array object to a C-style double array.

detaileddescription.para: This function provides a pointer to the underlying data of a PyArrayObject, assuming the PyArray is contiguous in memory. It allows C++ functions to directly access data passed from Python NumPy arrays.

parameterdescription.para: A pointer to the PyArrayObject to be converted.

simplesect.para: A pointer to the C-style double array representing the data.

briefdescription.para: Returns the size of the first dimension of a PyArrayObject.

detaileddescription.para: This function retrieves the size of the leading dimension of a NumPy array.

parameterdescription.para: A pointer to the PyArrayObject.

simplesect.para: An integer representing the size of the first dimension.

briefdescription.para: Calculates the amplitude of the potential.

detaileddescription.para: This function returns the value of the potential given the current field values and the parameters of the model.

parameterdescription.para: A pointer to the Python module object (standard PyMethodDef argument).
A tuple of Python arguments, expected to contain fieldsIn and params.

simplesect.para: A Python float (double) representing the potential value. Returns NULL on error.

briefdescription.para: Calculates the first derivatives (gradient) of the potential.

detaileddescription.para: This function returns a NumPy array containing the derivatives of the potential with respect to the fields, evaluated at the given fieldsIn and params.

parameterdescription.para: A pointer to the Python module object.
A tuple of Python arguments, expected to contain fieldsIn and params.

simplesect.para: A 1D NumPy array with the derivatives of the potential. Returns NULL on error.

briefdescription.para: Calculates the second derivatives (Hessian matrix) of the potential.

detaileddescription.para: This function returns a 2D NumPy array representing the Hessian matrix of the potential with respect to the fields, evaluated at fieldsIn and params.

parameterdescription.para: A pointer to the Python module object.
A tuple of Python arguments, expected to contain fieldsIn and params.

simplesect.para: A 2D NumPy array (nF x nF) with the Hessian matrix. Returns NULL on error.

detaileddescription.para: This function returns the value of the Hubble rate, given the current values of the fields and their velocities, along with the model parameters.

parameterdescription.para: A pointer to the Python module object.
A tuple of Python arguments, expected to contain fields_dfieldsIn and params.

simplesect.para: A Python float (double) representing the Hubble rate. Returns NULL on error.

briefdescription.para: Calculates the first slow-roll parameter, epsilon.

detaileddescription.para: This function computes the value of the first slow-roll parameter (epsilon), which is crucial for analyzing inflationary models, given the fields, velocities, and model parameters.

parameterdescription.para: A pointer to the Python module object.
A tuple of Python arguments, expected to contain fields_dfieldsIn and params.

simplesect.para: A Python float (double) representing the epsilon value. Returns NULL on error.

briefdescription.para: Calculates the second slow-roll parameter, eta.

detaileddescription.para: This function computes the value of the second slow-roll parameter (eta), which provides information about the curvature of the potential, given the fields, velocities, and model parameters.

parameterdescription.para: A pointer to the Python module object.
A tuple of Python arguments, expected to contain fields_dfieldsIn and params.

simplesect.para: A Python float (double) representing the eta value. Returns NULL on error.

briefdescription.para: Returns the number of fields in the defined inflationary model.

detaileddescription.para: This function provides the number of scalar fields used in the current model configuration. It takes no arguments and queries the underlying C++ model object.

parameterdescription.para: A pointer to the Python module object.
An empty tuple of Python arguments.

simplesect.para: A Python integer representing the number of fields. Returns NULL on error.

briefdescription.para: Returns the number of parameters for the defined inflationary model.

detaileddescription.para: This function provides the count of free parameters used in the current model configuration. It takes no arguments and queries the underlying C++ model object.

parameterdescription.para: A pointer to the Python module object.
An empty tuple of Python arguments.

simplesect.para: A Python integer representing the number of parameters. Returns NULL on error.

briefdescription.para: Computes the background evolution of fields and velocities.

detaileddescription.para: This function integrates the background evolution equations to find the trajectory of the fields and their velocities during inflation. It can return the evolution for specified time-steps or until the end of inflation (when epsilon > 1).

parameterdescription.para: A pointer to the Python module object.

A tuple of Python arguments containing:
t (PyArrayObject*): 1D NumPy array of time-steps (e-folds).
initialCs (PyArrayObject*): 1D NumPy array of initial field values and velocities.
params (PyArrayObject*): 1D NumPy array of model parameters.
tols (PyArrayObject*): 1D NumPy array (length 2) with absolute and relative tolerances for the RK45 integrator.
exit (bool): If true, evolve until inflation ends; otherwise, evolve for each t value.

simplesect.para: A 2D NumPy array (backOut) containing the background evolution. The shape depends on the exit flag and t. Returns NULL on error.

briefdescription.para: Computes the evolution of the 2-point correlation function (sigma).

detaileddescription.para: This function evolves the phase-space 2-point correlation function (sigma) for scalar perturbations over specified time-steps. It returns the full evolution or a condensed version depending on the full flag.

parameterdescription.para: A pointer to the Python module object.

A tuple of Python arguments containing:
t (PyArrayObject*): 1D NumPy array of time-steps (e-folds).
k (double): The value of the wavenumber.
initialCs (PyArrayObject*): 1D NumPy array of initial field values and velocities.
params (PyArrayObject*): 1D NumPy array of model parameters.
tols (PyArrayObject*): 1D NumPy array (length 2) with absolute and relative tolerances for RK45.
full (bool): If true, returns time, fields, velocities, power spectrum of zeta, and sigma. If false, returns time and power spectrum of zeta only.

simplesect.para: A 2D NumPy array (sigOut) containing the evolution of the 2-point function. The shape depends on the full flag. Returns NULL on error.

briefdescription.para: Computes the evolution of the 2-point correlation function for tensor perturbations (gamma).

detaileddescription.para: This function evolves the 2-point correlation function (gamma) for tensor perturbations over specified time-steps. It returns the full evolution or a condensed version depending on the full flag.

parameterdescription.para: A pointer to the Python module object.

A tuple of Python arguments containing:
t (PyArrayObject*): 1D NumPy array of time-steps (e-folds).
k (double): The value of the wavenumber.
initialCs (PyArrayObject*): 1D NumPy array of initial field values and velocities.
params (PyArrayObject*): 1D NumPy array of model parameters.
tols (PyArrayObject*): 1D NumPy array (length 2) with absolute and relative tolerances for RK45.
full (bool): If true, returns time, fields, velocities, power spectrum of zeta, and gamma. If false, returns time and power spectrum of zeta only.

simplesect.para: A 2D NumPy array (gamOut) containing the evolution of the 2-point tensor function. The shape depends on the full flag. Returns NULL on error.

briefdescription.para: Computes the evolution of the 3-point correlation function (alpha).

detaileddescription.para: This function evolves the 3-point correlation function (alpha) over specified time-steps for three given wavenumbers (k1, k2, k3). It returns the full evolution or a condensed version, including power spectra for each k mode and the bispectrum of zeta.

parameterdescription.para: A pointer to the Python module object.

A tuple of Python arguments containing:
t (PyArrayObject*): 1D NumPy array of time-steps (e-folds).
k1 (double): The value of the first wavenumber.
k2 (double): The value of the second wavenumber.
k3 (double): The value of the third wavenumber.
initialCs (PyArrayObject*): 1D NumPy array of initial field values and velocities.
params (PyArrayObject*): 1D NumPy array of model parameters.
tols (PyArrayObject*): 1D NumPy array (length 2) with absolute and relative tolerances for RK45.
full (bool): If true, returns time, fields, velocities, power spectra (k1, k2, k3), bispectrum of zeta, and alpha; otherwise, returns a condensed output.

simplesect.para: A 2D NumPy array (alpOut) containing the evolution of the 3-point function. The shape depends on the full flag. Returns NULL on error.

briefdescription.para: Computes the evolution of the 2-point Multi-Point Propagator (MPP2) matrix.

detaileddescription.para: This function evolves the MPP2 matrix (a 2-index multi-point propagator) over specified time-steps. It returns the time-evolution of the fields, velocities, and the elements of the MPP2 matrix.

parameterdescription.para: A pointer to the Python module object.

A tuple of Python arguments containing:
t (PyArrayObject*): 1D NumPy array of time-steps (e-folds).
k (double): The value of the wavenumber.
initialCs (PyArrayObject*): 1D NumPy array of initial field values and velocities.
params (PyArrayObject*): 1D NumPy array of model parameters.
tols (PyArrayObject*): 1D NumPy array (length 2) with absolute and relative tolerances for RK45.

simplesect.para: A 2D NumPy array (rhoOut) containing the evolution of the MPP2 matrix. Returns NULL on error.

briefdescription.para: Computes the 2-point correlation function (sigma) using the MPP formalism.

detaileddescription.para: This function calculates the evolution of the phase space two-point function (sigma) by utilizing the pre-computed MPP2 matrix. It can return the full evolution or the value at a specific time-step.

parameterdescription.para: A pointer to the Python module object.

A tuple of Python arguments containing:
t (PyArrayObject*): 1D NumPy array of time-steps (e-folds).
k (double): The value of the wavenumber.
initialCs (PyArrayObject*): 1D NumPy array of initial field values and velocities.
params (PyArrayObject*): 1D NumPy array of model parameters.
rho (PyArrayObject*): 2D NumPy array containing the pre-computed MPP2 matrix evolution.
full (bool): If true, returns time, zeta power spectrum, fields, velocities, and sigma. If false, returns time and zeta power spectrum only.
ts (double, optional): Specifies the desired time-step index (t[ts]) at which to compute sigma. If not provided, the function returns the entire evolution.

simplesect.para: A NumPy array (sigOut) containing the 2-point correlation function. The shape and content depend on full and ts. Returns NULL on error.

briefdescription.para: Computes the evolution of the 3-point Multi-Point Propagator (MPP3) matrices.

detaileddescription.para: This function evolves six MPP matrices: three 2-index (MPP2) matrices for each k mode (k1, k2, k3) and three 3-index (MPP3) matrices for each permutation of the three k modes. It uses the evolveRho3 function to compute the derivatives of all matrices.

parameterdescription.para: A pointer to the Python module object.

A tuple of Python arguments containing:
t (PyArrayObject*): 1D NumPy array of time-steps (e-folds).
k1 (double): The value of the first wavenumber.
k2 (double): The value of the second wavenumber.
k3 (double): The value of the third wavenumber.
initialCs (PyArrayObject*): 1D NumPy array of initial field values and velocities.
params (PyArrayObject*): 1D NumPy array of model parameters.
tols (PyArrayObject*): 1D NumPy array (length 2) with absolute and relative tolerances for RK45.

simplesect.para: A 2D NumPy array (rhoOut) containing the evolution of the fields, velocities, and all six MPP matrices. Returns NULL on error.

briefdescription.para: Computes the 3-point correlation function (alpha) using the MPP formalism.

detaileddescription.para: This function calculates the evolution of the phase space three-point function (alpha) by utilizing the pre-computed MPP3 matrices. It can return the full evolution or the value at a specific time-step, including power spectra for each k mode and the bispectrum of zeta.

parameterdescription.para: A pointer to the Python module object.

A tuple of Python arguments containing:
t (PyArrayObject*): 1D NumPy array of time-steps (e-folds).
k1 (double): The value of the first wavenumber.
k2 (double): The value of the second wavenumber.
k3 (double): The value of the third wavenumber.
initialCs (PyArrayObject*): 1D NumPy array of initial field values and velocities.
params (PyArrayObject*): 1D NumPy array of model parameters.
rho (PyArrayObject*): 2D NumPy array containing the pre-computed MPP3 matrices evolution.
full (bool): If true, returns comprehensive output including fields, velocities, all sigma matrices, and alpha; otherwise, returns a condensed output.
ts (double, optional): Specifies the desired time-step index (t[ts]) at which to compute alpha. If not provided, the function returns the entire evolution.

simplesect.para: A NumPy array (alpROut) containing the 3-point correlation function. The shape and content depend on full and ts. Returns NULL on error.

briefdescription.para: Core C++ implementations for the PyTransport 3.0 module.

detaileddescription.para: This file defines the C++ functions that are exposed to Python through the PyTransport module. It provides the numerical backbone for computing primordial correlators in inflationary cosmology, implementing both the standard Transport formalism and the Multi-point propagator (MPP) approach.

simplesect.para: 3.0.7 (Corrected Logic and Memory Initialization)
Andrea Costantini, David Mulryne, John W. Ronayne

sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: PyTransport constitutes a straightforward code written in C++ together with Python scripts which automatically edit, compile and run the C++ code as a Python module. It has been written for Unix-like systems (OS X and Linux). PyTransport relies on the Transport formalism, which implements a differential formalism to compute inflationary correlation functions. It is able to compute tree-level correlators for multi-field models with canonical and non-canonical field space. Along with the standard Transport formalism, PyTransport 3.0 also implements the Multi-point propagator (MPP) approach to inflationary correlators. The MPP approach provides an alternative way to compute two- and three-point correlation functions, and related observables, with advantages and limits discussed in related literature.
